I treat failure as feedback. I reflect, talk to peers if needed, and extract what I can learn. Mistakes have been my biggest teachers — whether it's a bug in production or a communication slip, I come back stronger.

text: How do you deal with pressure or high-stress situations?

text: Describe a challenging time at work and how you handled it.

metadata.answer:
Challenging Time

There was a time when a critical production bug affected the checkout experience on a live payment gateway used by hundreds of dealerships. The issue was intermittent, caused only under specific race conditions between tokenization and charge flows.

Initial panic: It wasn't reproducible in staging, which made debugging even harder.

What I Did:

  • Quickly introduced conditional logging & audit trails to monitor backend flows without disrupting users
  • Simulated real-time race conditions using local mocks and controlled delays
  • Worked closely with the QA team and business users to gather patterns from failed transactions
  • Identified a mismatch in handling of async responses between FortisPay's webhook & client-side confirmations

Outcome:

We deployed a fix within 24 hours. I also wrote a retro and built a chaos-test harness for future edge cases. The leadership appreciated not just the fix, but how transparently it was communicated and handled.

text: How did you build this app?

metadata.answer:
🛠️ How I Built This App

This app is powered by a combination of AI, vector search, and clean front-end magic ✨

  • ⚙️ Backend: I used Python + FastAPI to create APIs that handle vector search and data management.
  • 📚 Vector Search: I'm using ChromaDB to store all the text+metadata and perform similarity searches using sentence embeddings.
  • 🧠 Embeddings: I used a Sentence Transformer model to convert questions and answers into vectors so they can be matched semantically — even if the question isn't asked exactly the same way.
  • 💻 Frontend: Built using React, which sends the question to the backend and renders the rich HTML answer beautifully (with support for dark and light themes).
  • 💡 Fun Additions: Custom context, dynamic rendering, HTML formatting, and conversational tone make it feel more like a real conversation with me!

It's lightweight, personalized, and super fun to build 😄

text: What's your approach to learning new technologies?

metadata.answer:
📚 My Approach to Learning New Tech

I love learning new technologies — it keeps me sharp and curious! 🔍 My approach is hands-on and structured:

  • Start Small: I begin with the official docs and beginner-friendly tutorials to understand the fundamentals.
  • Build Something: I quickly move on to side projects or small POCs. I believe in learning by doing.
  • Explore Real Use Cases: I dig into how real-world companies use the tech through GitHub repos, blog posts, or engineering blogs.
  • Join Communities: I follow dev communities on Reddit, Twitter, Discord, etc. to stay updated and ask questions.
  • Document & Teach: I note down learnings and share them through internal documentation or with peers — teaching reinforces knowledge 🧠

Whether it's a new frontend framework, a backend tool, or cloud tech, I'm always excited to dive in, experiment, and master it 💡
